title: Inversnaid Falls Walking Route

images.title: John Fielding / Inversnaid Falls
images.caption: Inversnaid Falls. From a boat on Loch Lomond, to the left of pic is Inversnaid Hotel.

images.title: Ian Taylor / Waterfall
images.caption: Waterfall following typical wet weather. Bridge above falls carries West Highland Way. Gerald Manley Hopkin's short poem ("Inversnaid") is about this waterfall. Its final well-known lines are even more appropriate now: "What would the world be, once bereft Of wet and of wildness? Let them be left, O let them be left, wildness and wet; Long live the weeds and the wilderness yet."

images.title: Footbridge over the Falls by John Myers, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Footbridge over the Falls

images.caption: Loch Lomond Waterfall

images.title: Inversnaid Falls by Jo Turner, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Inversnaid Falls

description: Visit these beautiful falls next to Loch Lomond on this short walk. The route starts at the Inversnaid Hotel before a short stroll takes you to the falls on Arklet Water. You can then continue your walk by climbing through the surrounding woodland and heading along the loch using the West Highland Way . You could also extend your walk by visiting the RSPB Inversnaid Nature Trail where you can look out for a variety of wildlife.
